author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: Sometimes, All You Need Is a Wacky Shoe
description: And this was one for the ages.
content: At the Ferrari fashion show early Saturday morning, I beheld a shoe that would surely make design professors yank their hair out, that broke several codes of good taste at once, that pretty much distracted me from seeing anything else in the show. As I said to a seat mate at the show, it was the most deranged shoe I could recall seeing in … years?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: ‘This Is Going to Be Great Television’: Trump Sums Up His Zelensky Showdown
description: The ratings are never far from President Trump’s mind.
content: One of the most surreal moments of Friday’s Oval Office showdown between President Trump and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine came at the very end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: How Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie Wrote Her Way Through Loss
description: When her father died, the author of “Americanah” produced a slim work of nonfiction. When her mother died, she poured her grief into a sprawling 416-page novel.
content: To walk into Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie’s stately brick home outside Baltimore is to know, beyond a shadow of a doubt, that small children live there. It’s not that the kitchen floor is a Lego minefield or that the double staircase is lined with low-hanging fingerprints — quite the opposite. It’s that the house rings with expectancy, as if biding time until the next step in a carefully choreographed routine, which, if you think about it, isn’t all that different from the mood in the lead-up to a much-anticipated book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Cuomo Enters N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race, Upending Contest to Unseat Adams
description: The comeback attempt, three years after Andrew M. Cuomo resigned as governor in scandal, will test New Yorkers’ appetite for second chances, and change.
content: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Saturday that he would run for mayor of New York City, upending the race to unseat Eric Adams and setting up an audacious comeback attempt three years after he resigned in disgrace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Trump and Vance Are Stripping Away Foreign Policy Illusions
description: But realism needs more diplomacy to work.
content: Donald Trump, Henry Kissinger remarked in 2018, “may be one of those figures in history who appears from time to time to mark the end of an era and to force it to give up its old pretenses.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Michael Levenson
title: In U.S., Tate Brothers Are Met With a Mixed Reception
description: Their arrival has upset their accusers and alarmed women’s rights groups. Conservatives were divided.
content: Andrew Tate rose to fame on a message of forceful masculinity that positioned men as rightful dominators over women. From his base in Romania, he promised to help guide men through “the Matrix,” his conspiratorial term for a world that he says unfairly demonizes men, and called the criminal accusations against him evidence of persecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian Brave NoiseCat
title: I Told a Native Story That Earned an Oscar Nomination. There Are So Many More to Tell.
description: “Sugarcane” is a documentary about abuse at Native residential schools. It’s just one of many stories that demand to be told.
content: Four years ago, a ground-penetrating radar study commissioned by the Tk’emlups te Secwépemc First Nation identified evidence of about 200 child-size graves on the grounds of the Kamloops Indian Residential School in British Columbia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 1, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 1, 2025.
content: An article on Friday about President Trump’s proposal for a new “gold card” visa program described incorrectly a golden visa program in the European Union. Some golden visa holders are entitled to visa-free travel within certain areas of the European Union, but residence is restricted to the specific country that issued the visa; it is not the case that they allow recipients to establish residency in any country in the bloc.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaad D'Souza
title: Bruno Mars Is Pop’s Most Reliable Male Star. Who Is He, Really?
description: A schmaltzy ballad. A bubble-gum pop song. A raunchy rap anthem. All three Hot 100 hits feature Mars, a blockbuster singer and songwriter who is largely a cipher.
content: It’s a free-for-all on the Hot 100 chart right now. “Die With a Smile,” a slick, sappy Lady Gaga ballad destined for oldies radio rotation in about 20 years, has been hovering around No. 1 since summer. “Apt.,” a peppy new wave-inspired cut by Blackpink’s Rosé that speaks the rhythmic, hyperactive language of TikTok, is also in the Top 10. And a little further down, there’s Sexyy Red’s “Fat, Juicy and Wet,” the kind of raunchy, would-be strip club anthem that seems to float into the mainstream every few years. Nothing really links these songs — except for the fact that Bruno Mars appears on all three.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: A Scoop in the Mail
description: Susanne Craig, an investigative reporter at The Times, was astonished to see that a manila envelope that landed in her mailbox contained pages from Donald Trump’s tax records.
content: Donald J. Trump’s 1995 income tax returns arrived at The New York Times through the mail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Maggie Haberman and Annie Correal
title: Honduras Moves to Extradite Man Accused of Killing Iowa Woman
description: In his 2016 campaign, President Trump seized on the death of Sarah Root, who police said was killed by an undocumented immigrant suspected of driving drunk.
content: The government of Honduras said it had begun the process of extraditing to the United States an undocumented immigrant who was accused of killing a young Iowa woman in 2016, a case that President Trump made a focal point in his first presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Safak Timur and Carlotta Gall
title: Kurdish Insurgent Group Declares Cease-Fire in Conflict With Turkey
description: The group, the P.K.K., made its declaration days after its long-imprisoned leader urged the movement to disarm and disband, but there are still many questions about the prospects for ending 40 years of deadly conflict.
content: The Kurdish guerrilla group that has been fighting a long-running insurgency against Turkey declared a cease-fire on Saturday, days after a call from its jailed leader to disarm and disband the organization raised hopes of ending a conflict that has killed tens of thousands of people over four decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren
title: Homeland Security Officials Push I.R.S. for 700,000 Immigrants’ Addresses
description: The tax collector has so far denied the request because of concerns it violates taxpayer privacy laws.
content: The Department of Homeland Security has pushed the Internal Revenue Service to turn over the addresses of roughly 700,000 undocumented immigrants it is seeking to deport, according to three people familiar with the matter, in a request that could violate taxpayer privacy laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: In Showdown With Zelensky, Trump Takes Offense on Putin’s Behalf
description: Never in the past few decades at least has an American president engaged in such an angry, scathing attack on a visiting foreign leader in the Oval Office.
content: It went well enough for the first 23 minutes, a polite if stiff meeting between an American president and a foreign leader. Then their differences started to be aired, unmistakably though not too contentiously. Then after 39 minutes, it really came off the rails.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 Books for Jazz Age Enthusiasts
description: A Scott and Zelda roman à clef; a photo collection of 1920s Paris.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Tannenbaum
title: David Johansen: 15 Essential Songs
description: He was the frontman of the New York Dolls, an adventurous solo performer and the lounge act Buster Poindexter. Listen to highlights from his eclectic catalog.
content: It’s a paradox that Staten Island, New York City’s most conservative borough, produced David Johansen, one of its most outrageous frontmen. Johansen led the New York Dolls, five bright-eyed boys who dressed flamboyantly and dreamed of sounding like the Shirelles crossed with a midtown traffic jam. He died on Friday, at age 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘Nickel Boys,’ an Oscar Nominee With a Jarringly Different Point of View
description: RaMell Ross subverts our gaze again, as he did with the documentary “Hale County This Morning, This Evening,” another Academy Award contender.
content: It’s incredibly rare — in fact, I don’t think it’s ever happened before this year — for a filmmaker to get an Oscar-nomination for a documentary and then land a best picture nomination for their next feature film. (A few have come close, though, and Ava DuVernay pulled it off, but in the opposite order.) Part of the blame lies with the Academy, which has somehow never nominated a documentary for Best Picture. It’s also just difficult, though by no means impossible, to excel in both fiction and nonfiction in a way that captures voter attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mimi Dwyer, Michael Wines and Loren Elliott For The New York Times
title: Beneath Yosemite’s Beauty, Anger and Anxiety Over Trump’s Job Cuts
description: Tensions over cost-cutting and maintaining Yosemite have been building, as fired federal workers stage protests at the country’s third-oldest national park.
content: Some might call Elliot Lozano, a 37-year-old biological science technician and weasel specialist, a prime example of why the Trump administration chose to cut 1,000 jobs from the National Park Service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon and Drew Atkins
title: Judge Blocks Trump’s Plan to End Funds for Trans Youth Health Providers in 4 States
description: The states — Washington, Oregon, Minnesota and Colorado — had sued to block President Trump’s plan to withhold federal funds from hospitals that offer transgender treatment to people under 19.
content: A federal judge in Seattle issued a preliminary injunction late Friday blocking the government from withholding federal funds from hospitals in four states that offer gender-transition treatment for people under 19. The decision dealt a setback to a key part of the Trump administration’s broad effort to limit the official recognition of transgender identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien
title: Keep an Invasive Species in Check: Eat a Big Rat-Like Rodent, U.S. Says
description: The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service said Americans should hunt and cook nutrias, an invasive species found in marshy areas, to help curb their population.
content: The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service has a suggestion to help curb the growing population of an invasive species that bears a resemblance to a very large rat: Eat them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova and Daniel Lozado
title: A Famous Bathtub Finds a New Home
description: The tub from a steamy scene in the film “Saltburn” is now on display inside a passionate fan’s house.
content: Anyone who has watched “Saltburn” probably remembers the scene, and some who have not seen the dark coming-of-age thriller about two Oxford students may remember it, too: The part when middle-class Oliver (Barry Keoghan), while visiting the country estate of his wealthy friend Felix (Jacob Elordi), surreptitiously watches him take a bath and then slurps up the leftover water as it streams down the drain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Barron, Kate LoPresti, Tina Antolini, Wendy Dorr, Carole Sabouraud, Melissa Kirsch, Kyle Buchanan and Manohla Dargis
title: Our Guide to the 2025 Oscars
description: Who will win? Who should win?
content: The 97th Academy Awards are on Sunday, bringing an end to an awards season that has been full of twists and turns. After some nominees picked up unexpected wins at previous ceremonies and others became ensnarled in online controversies, many races are still up in the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada-U.S. Relations Continue to Reach Lows Over Tariffs and Annexation Threats
description: President Trump said he would impose potentially devastating tariffs on Tuesday, inspiring patriotism in Canada.
content: President Trump and Vice President JD Vance’s televised berating of President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine suggests that things could be worse between Canada and the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi and Zach Montague
title: Judge Appears Skeptical of Claims That Musk Isn’t Driving DOGE
description: The judge prodded government lawyers for additional clarity on Elon Musk’s role in a case that directly challenges the constitutionality of his operation and his part in the rapid reshaping of government.
content: A federal judge said on Friday that it seemed “factually inaccurate” for the Trump administration to keep insisting that Elon Musk has no formal position in an operation that has led to mass firings of federal workers and the hobbling of the nation’s foreign aid agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro
title: Governor Maura Healey Wants Democrats to Put Up a Fight
description: The Massachusetts leader, whose influence goes well beyond her state, discusses how the Democratic Party can pick its battles and rebuild its brand.
content: Democratic governors are in a tricky spot. If they defy President Trump, they are liable to find themselves retaliated against, as happened last week to Gov. Janet Mills of Maine, whose state become the subject of a Trump-administration investigation after she sparred with the president during the annual National Governors Association meeting over his executive order banning transgender athletes from women’s sports. But appeasing or ignoring an emboldened Trump leaves them vulnerable to an increasingly angry Democratic base that wants to see their elected officials fight back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Luke Broadwater
title: How Johnson, Who Put His Job at Risk to Save Ukraine Aid, Flipped for Trump
description: Many Republicans have made a reversal on Russia and Ukraine, falling in line behind President Trump. No turnabout has been more striking than that of the Republican speaker.
content: The night before Speaker Mike Johnson defied the hard-right wing of his party and brought up a bill to send more than $60 billion in aid to Ukraine, he spent a mostly sleepless night in a luxury hotel suite overlooking the Potomac River, bracing for a mutiny that would end his speakership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: A Timeline of Andrew Cuomo’s Rise, Fall and Re-emergence
description: Mr. Cuomo has twice had his political career written off and managed to come back. A look at some of the key moments in his career.
content: Andrew M. Cuomo’s entry in the race for mayor of New York City is yet another dramatic twist in the former governor’s long history in the public eye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: Europe Rallies Around Zelensky After Explosive White House Meeting
description: The statements piled up on social media, offering words of encouragement to the Ukrainian leader and his people.
content: European leaders quickly pledged their continued support for Ukraine on Friday after President Trump’s blistering criticism of Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, in a meeting at the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Hair Transplants and the New Male Vanity
description: Maximal transparency is fine, but can’t anybody age naturally anymore?
content: Last year, I noticed that two comedians I like talked about getting hair transplants. One of them, Matteo Lane, named his special “Hair Plugs & Heartache,” which opens with an extended bit about the transplant experience. I appreciated Lane’s radical (and very funny) transparency regarding the cosmetic enhancement. He talked about the expense, described the 10-hour surgery and the long recovery, and joked about his hair growing in gradually “like a Chia pet.” He’s very happy with the outcome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Inside the Democratic Disaster That Didn’t Happen in November
description: The party’s storehouse of everything it knows about American voters required an extraordinary intervention to keep it running, people involved said. A meltdown could have crippled its campaigns nationwide.
content: Problems with a huge database of voter information that effectively functions as the central nervous system of the Democratic Party grew so worrisome last summer that top Democrats staged an extraordinary intervention to keep it running through the November election, according to multiple people involved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: The Tiny Brown Hare Who Taught One Woman to Slow Down
description: In her memoir, “Raising Hare,” Chloe Dalton describes how a leveret changed her outlook on life during the pandemic and beyond.
content: During the lockdowns of the Covid-19 pandemic, the internet was the lifeline to work, school, entertainment and social activity for many white-collar workers. Yet, when her router cable was severed, Chloe Dalton felt not panic, but “a rare moment of exasperation” with the toothy perpetrator — the brown hare with whom she’d been sharing her home in the English countryside. “I sighed,” she writes. “She had snipped through the TV cable as well.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Julia Jacobs
title: Mystery of Gene Hackman’s Death Brings Grief and Bewilderment to Santa Fe
description: Residents mourning Mr. Hackman and his wife, Betsy Arakawa, are consumed by the unusual circumstances surrounding their deaths and why they were not discovered sooner.
content: Settling in for a drink the other night at Jinja, the restaurant in Santa Fe, N.M., that Gene Hackman and his wife dined at and had invested in, a group of patrons decided to honor the couple by ordering a round of “Gene’s Mai-Tais” off the menu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What’s Really Going On With Versace?
description: The show was a mess, but it’s complicated.
content: Versace had me with the opener — strapless, corseted evening looks with gathered puffer skirts, like wearable black tie sleeping bags — but it lost me with the cheetah-print teddy under a black suit jacket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Hazel N. Dukes, Longtime Civil Rights Stalwart, Dies at 92
description: She was president of the national N.A.A.C.P. in the early 1990s and headed the organization’s New York State Conference from 1977 until her death.
content: Hazel N. Dukes, an early and unwavering crusader for civil rights who survived personal, professional and political setbacks to serve for nearly a half-century as the perennial president of New York State’s N.A.A.C.P., died on Saturday at her home in Harlem. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: We Need to Talk About the Lying
description: Trump promised and promised and promised.
content: During the presidential campaign, Donald Trump promised the moon. He promised he would not cut Social Security. He vowed to protect Medicare. He promised free in vitro fertilization. He disavowed the Heritage Foundation’s Project 2025 and promised that he had “nothing” to do with it. He promised he would lower the cost of housing, groceries and other necessities. He promised cheaper eggs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Nataliya Vasilyeva and Paul Sonne
title: Trump’s Dressing Down of Zelensky Plays Into Putin’s War Aims
description: The public blowup could propel President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to escalate the fight in Ukraine instead of agreeing to peace.
content: President Trump says he wants a quick cease-fire in Ukraine. But President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appears to be in no rush, and the blowup on Friday between Mr. Trump and Ukraine’s president may give Russia’s leader the kind of ammunition he needs to prolong the fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Francis Collins Retires From N.I.H., Saying Colleagues ‘Deserve the Utmost Respect’
description: Dr. Collins, a renowned geneticist, ran the National Institutes of Health for 12 years. His parting statement offered a pointed, if veiled, message to the Trump administration.
content: Dr. Francis S. Collins, a renowned geneticist who ran the National Institutes of Health for 12 years, announced Saturday that he has retired from the institutes and the federal government, issuing a parting statement that offered a pointed, if somewhat veiled, message to the Trump administration, which has fired hundreds of N.I.H. employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Diamond
title: The Rings Adriana Paz Keeps Close
description: The Mexican actress, a star in the Oscar nominated film “Emilia Perez,” wears these to tether her to home, especially when work has taken her away.
content: The ring collection of the Mexican actress Adriana Paz has its own stories to tell. There is the mood ring a Swedish stranger gave her, once upon a time, at a “hippie hostel” where she literally sang for her dinner. And the ring made of silver hearts that the Spanish actress Maribel Verdú slipped on Ms. Paz’s finger while asking, in the style of a classic playground proposal, “Do you want to be my friend?”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: A Cash Shortage Threatens Ramadan Festivities in Syria
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 1, 2025.
content: “We have now gotten to a point in Syria where even a cup of coffee may be too much of a hardship for someone to offer you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annik LaFarge
title: Overlooked No More: Maria W. Stewart, Trailblazing Voice for Black Women
description: She was the first Black woman to publicly address other women, using essays and lectures in the 1830s to champion their rights and challenge oppression.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Fighting Musk’s Secrecy, in Court
description: The lack of transparency surrounding the so-called Department of Government Efficiency is emerging as a target in the courts.
content: Elon Musk likes to talk about transparency. But a major story my colleagues published today shows how he baked secrecy into his Department of Government Efficiency from the start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Carol Rosenberg
title: New Lawsuit Challenges Legality of Trump’s Sending Migrants to Guantánamo
description: The new case, which for now is asking for a court to block the transfer of 10 men to the offshore base, is the first to directly challenge the policy.
content: The Trump administration faced the first direct legal challenge to its policy of sending migrants to the U.S. military base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, for continued immigration detention with a lawsuit filed on Saturday by a coalition of human rights and immigrant advocacy organizations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By M. Gessen
title: Putin Is Ready to Carve Up the World. Trump Just Handed Him the Knife.
description: The talks about Ukraine were never just about Ukraine.
content: Washington and Moscow have been repairing relations at breakneck speed, comparable only to the speed at which the Trump administration is breaking things at home. After meeting with Secretary of State Marco Rubio in Saudi Arabia on Feb. 18, the Russian foreign minister, Sergei Lavrov, said the two sides had resolved to “eliminate impediments” to improving bilateral relations, a phrasing that sent chills down the spines of Russian exiles — myself included — who have sought what at the time seemed like safe harbor in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Oscars Audience Size Poses a Test: Is Hollywood Still Culturally Relevant?
description: Worries about the award show’s TV viewership, a barometer of the industry’s influence, are rumbling through the movie capital.
content: Viewership for the annual Oscars show has long served as a cultural barometer — a way for Hollywood to gauge its relevance amid shifting political winds, fracturing media habits and changing social values.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
title: Trump Relaxes Limits on Counterterrorism Strikes Outside Conventional War Zones
description: The president has rescinded a Biden-era system that required high-level approval for certain drone strikes and commando raids, reverting to a more permissive system.
content: President Trump has rescinded Biden-era limits on counterterrorism drone strikes and commando raids outside conventional war zones, reverting to the looser set of rules he used in his first term, according to officials familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft, Stacey Solie and Erin Trieb
title: Thousands Gather at National Parks Across U.S. to Protest Job Cuts
description: From Acadia in Maine to Joshua Tree in Southern California, protesters turned out to stand up against what they see as threats to public lands.
content: Thousands of people gathered on Saturday at national parks from California to Maine to protest the Trump administration’s firing of at least 1,000 National Park Service employees last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: Trump’s ‘Gold Card’ Set Off Panic in an Unexpected Place: Real Estate
description: The president initially said his $5 million green card alternative would replace a visa for foreign investors that has become a favorite financing tool of major developers.
content: President Trump’s plan to sell green cards for $5 million each, a program he is calling a “gold card,” has largely been met with a shrug. It’s not clear exactly how the program would work, if it’s legal or how many potential immigrants would really pay $5 million for a path to U.S. citizenship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bilal Shbair, Abu Bakr Bashir and Aaron Boxerman
title: Gazans Mark a Somber Ramadan Amid the Rubble
description: “This Ramadan is nothing like the ones before,” said one resident as the holy fasting month for Muslims began. “The war has drained it of meaning.”
content: Bags of fragrant spices, crates of dates, frozen chicken and fresh produce. Food and other goods that were scarce during the war have returned to the shops and street markets of Gaza in time for the holy fasting month of Ramadan. And the Israeli bombs have fallen silent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Amber Bracken
title: Canada Curbed Illegal Migration to the U.S. Now People Are Heading to Canada.
description: The Canadian government has reinforced border operations to stop migrants going to the United States, a major Trump complaint. But early data shows people are, instead, starting to flee the United States for Canada.
content: The pre-dawn call by U.S. border agents to their Canadian counterparts was shocking: A group of nine people, most of them children, were about to enter Canada on foot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Christian Holder, Longtime Star of the Joffrey Ballet, Dies at 75
description: He brought his elegance and power to boundary-pushing ballets in the 1960s and ’70s, and he was a presence at the storied company for 13 years.
content: Christian Holder, a standout dancer for the Joffrey Ballet who made his name in the 1960s and early ’70s in pointedly topical works like “Astarte,” a groundbreaking psychedelic ballet, and “The Green Table,” a haunting 1930s antiwar ballet made newly relevant by the Vietnam War, died on Feb. 18 at his home in London. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Sensible Guide
description: Ryan Judge’s puzzle invites solvers to go for a spin.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Ryan Judge has constructed two prior puzzles for The New York Times, both of them themeless — one ran on a Friday and the other on a Saturday. For all the solvers who enjoy guessing which day a puzzle should fall on based on its difficulty, today’s began as a Friday but was upgraded to a Saturday. I think it’s a good example of what a fine line there is between the two days. Truth be told, I often wonder what would happen if a themeless puzzle that was discernibly easier ran regularly on Tuesdays or Wednesdays instead of later in the week and then Friday puzzles came with difficult themes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: How Patina Miller, of Starz’s ‘Power’ Series, Spends Her Sundays
description: The Tony Award-winning actress fits in a long run before her daughter’s swim class and time in the recording studio.
content: Patina Miller may play a fearless New York City drug queenpin inspired by 50 Cent’s mother on television, but for a long time, something scared her: having a child of her own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Trump Is Rootin’ for Putin
description: Trump and Vance in a gross betrayal of the West.
content: It was a sickening spectacle: the man who tried to upend democracy bullying the man who is fighting for democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn
title: Ukrainians Blindsided by Deal’s Breakdown and by Trump’s Actions
description: Some said they felt the U.S. president was disrespectful and that they were proud of their leader for standing up to him.
content: Liudmyla Shestakova has lost a lot to this war — her son, and his wife, who died together on the front lines. But she’s a realist, like many in this mining region in central Ukraine. And ever since President Trump suggested it, she has thought that her country should sign a proposed deal that would give America some profits from mining in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: A New Age of Iranian Cinema Is on Display at the Oscars
description: “The Seed of the Sacred Fig,” an Oscar-nominated movie filmed in secret in Iran, highlights the Iranian film world’s groundbreaking new work, inspired by the women-led protests in 2022.
content: A wife, wearing a nightgown and her hair uncovered, lies down next to her husband in bed. An older man and woman, drunk on red wine, dance wildly and discuss the complexities of sex and nudity at their age. A distressed young woman navigates the sexual advances of a male employer in a job interview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,352
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, March 2, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: A Day of American Infamy
description: A dreadful moment for Ukraine, for the free world, for the legacy of an America that once stood for the principles of the Atlantic Charter.
content: In August 1941, about four months before the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, Franklin Roosevelt met with Winston Churchill aboard warships in Newfoundland’s Placentia Bay and agreed to the Atlantic Charter, a joint declaration by the world’s leading democratic powers on “common principles” for a postwar world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye and Brian Karlsson
title: It’s Been Five Years Since New York Banned Single-Use Plastic Bags. They’re Still Floating Around.
description: The muse of American Beauty, Katy Perry and bathroom trash cans everywhere just won’t go away.
content: Since New York’s ban on the distribution of single-use plastic bags took effect five years ago, Francisco Marte, who owns five bodegas in the Bronx with his brothers, has been conflicted about how to transition away from their use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Trump Picks Another Trade Fight With Canada Over Lumber
description: The president initiated an investigation that could lead to tariffs on lumber imports, nearly half of which comes from Canada.
content: President Trump on Saturday initiated an investigation into whether imports of lumber threaten America’s national security, a step that is likely to further inflame relations with Canada, the largest exporter of wood to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: The New American Gun Store: Grips, Grenade Launchers and Ramen Noodles
description: A new crop of retailers is profiting more from limited-edition accessories that sell out in minutes, and promoting lifestyle gear to women, minority gun owners and the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
content: Christmas was a few days away and Solomon Lehnerd was selling more grenade launchers than usual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: The ‘S.N.L.’ Hosts Who Give 110%
description: A look back at the pro athletes who have tested their fortitude at 30 Rock. “Sometimes it’s a train wreck,” a producer said. Or an incredible surprise.
content: “Saturday Night Live,” which is celebrating its 50th season this year, has had hundreds of hosts. There are the famous actors, the musicians and the comedians, of course. And then there are the professional athletes who are used to performing on fields, tracks and courts, not on a stage at 30 Rockefeller Plaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Behind the Collision: Trump Jettisons Ukraine on His Way to a Larger Goal
description: The president’s explosive Oval Office encounter reflected his determination to put aside alliances and commitments to principles in favor of raw great power negotiations.
content: After five weeks in which President Trump made clear his determination to scrap America’s traditional sources of power — its alliances among like-minded democracies — and return the country to an era of raw great-power negotiations, he left one question hanging: How far would he go in sacrificing Ukraine to his vision?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Pentagon Sending Combat Forces to the Border in Line With Trump Directive
description: The troop mobilization indicates that President Trump is breaking with recent presidents’ practice of limiting deployments along the U.S.-Mexico border mostly to small numbers of active-duty soldiers and reservists.
content: The Pentagon is sending about 3,000 additional troops to the southwestern border, rushing to comply with President Trump’s order to increase the military’s role in stemming the flow of migrants into the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: More Women File Lawsuits Against Brothers Accused of Sex Crimes
description: Tal Alexander and his brothers, Oren Alexander and Alon Alexander, who are twins, now face at least 24 civil lawsuits, as they await trial on federal sex-trafficking charges.
content: Seven lawsuits were filed this week against one or more of the Alexander brothers, who are facing multiple accusations of sexual assault in both civil and criminal court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Intelligence Officials Continue Chat Messages Inquiry
description: Officials confirmed that the N.S.A. managed a system that had been used for sexually explicit chats and L.G.B.T.Q. discussions. An order to fire dozens after the chats were revealed drew scrutiny amid a military purge of transgender soldiers.
content: Intelligence officials are continuing to investigate sexually explicit messages that were posted on a government chat tool, the National Security Agency said Friday, exchanges that prompted the nation’s top intelligence official to order the firing of more than 100 officers this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Fugitive in 1982 Bombing Lived as Dead Classmate in New Mexico, U.S. Says
description: Stephen Craig Campbell was accused of planting an explosive device at the doorstep of the boyfriend of his estranged wife. He hid as Walter Lee Coffman, who was dead almost 50 years, the authorities said.
content: For decades, a man lived as Walter Lee Coffman, using his Social Security number, obtaining a driver’s license and passports, purchasing property and even cashing more than $100,000 in government retirement benefits, Justice Department officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Musk and Republican Lawmakers Pressure Judges with Impeachment Threats
description: Democrats say the calls to remove judges who block Trump administration initiatives amount to intimidation. Some senior Republicans are also skeptical of the effort.
content: Congressional Republicans, egged on by Elon Musk and other top allies of President Trump, are escalating calls to remove federal judges who stand in the way of administration efforts to overhaul the government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Graff and Camille Baker
title: Cuts to National Weather Service Leave Forecasters Reeling
description: “Lives are being put in danger,” one meteorologist warned, as some experts feared the cuts will harm public safety.
content: Twice a day for years, meteorologists in Kotzebue, Alaska, have launched weather balloons far into the sky to measure data like wind speed, humidity and temperature, and translated the information the balloons sent back into weather forecasts and models. It’s a ritual repeated at dozens of weather stations around the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Burdick
title: How Fungi Move Among Us
description: Underground fungal networks are “living algorithms” that quietly help regulate Earth’s climate. Now scientists know what makes them so efficient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: With Netflix Show, Meghan Tries for Lifestyle Maven Status
description: The Duchess of Sussex has tried to channel the likes of Martha Stewart for years. Can “With Love, Meghan” get her there?
content: “With Love, Meghan,” the new Netflix lifestyle series premiering next week, is a culmination of sorts for its creator and star, Meghan, Duchess of Sussex. The show casts the duchess as a perfectly groomed domestic goddess, cooking and entertaining for friends at home in coastal California, a role to which she has seemingly aspired for more than a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: Despite Efforts to Save It, a Beloved Pink House in Massachusetts Will Be Razed
description: Gov. Maura Healey, lamenting the decision, called the house “a special part of the history, culture and fabric” of the coastal region north of Boston.
content: A battered pink house on the coast of Massachusetts, beloved by generations of artists and romantics, will be torn down by the federal government in March, ending a yearslong fight to save it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Rainbow Connection
description: Adam Wagner’s puzzle is for the lovers, the dreamers and everyone else.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kiuko Notoya and Martin Fackler
title: Why a Japanese Oscar Contender Isn’t Being Shown in Japan
description: Shiori Ito’s searing indictment of Japan’s justice system in handling sexual assault cases is nominated for best documentary feature at Sunday’s Academy Awards.
content: A film by a Japanese woman about her search for justice from uncooperative authorities after she reported being raped is a contender at Sunday’s Academy Awards. Yet, despite being the first full-length documentary made by a Japanese director ever nominated for an Oscar, the movie cannot be seen in her home country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Oval Office Showdown
description: A venomous public spat made it clear that President Trump regards Ukraine as an obstacle.
content: After five weeks in which President Trump made clear his determination to scrap America’s traditional sources of power — its alliances among like-minded democracies — and return the country to an era of great-power negotiations, he left one question hanging: How far would he go in sacrificing Ukraine to his vision?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Welcome to the Zero Sum Era. Now How Do We Get Out?
description: Zero-sum thinking has spread like a mind virus, from geopolitics to pop culture.
content: My grandfather’s idea of an Easter egg hunt involved hiding money in colorful plastic eggs sprinkled around his house on Long Island. Most held coins, but there was always one with a crisp, new $100 bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: The Dark Heart of Trump’s Foreign Policy
description: The journalist Fareed Zakaria discusses the worldview emerging from Trump’s foreign policy decisions regarding Ukraine, Gaza, China and beyond.
content: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Alexandra Stevenson, Danielle Kaye and Eli Tan
title: ‘How Are We Going to Afford This?’ U.S. Companies Face Tariff Reality.
description: Business owners told The Times that President Trump’s tariffs could lead to higher costs and expressed frustration at the sudden uncertainty about policy.
content: From her home in Phoenix, Erica Campbell is waiting for a cargo vessel from China to deliver a shipment of thousands of Jesus rattle dolls, tin Easter eggs, religious-themed baby swaddle blankets and 15,000 packages of Jesus Heals bandages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Black Leaders on Why They’ve Turned Against Eric Adams
description: The mayor is losing support from a crucial cohort whose members say he is damaging the political prospects of other Black officials.
content: The speech by Mayor Eric Adams of New York City, in the closing week of Black History Month, seemed to be hitting all the right historical notes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: FedEx Plane Lands at Newark Airport With Engine on Fire After Striking Bird
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which runs the airport, said that the plane landed on Saturday morning and that there were no reported injuries.
content: A FedEx cargo plane was forced to make an emergency landing on Saturday morning at Newark Liberty International Airport with one of its engines on fire after it struck a bird while leaving the airport, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Pager and Maggie Haberman
title: How Zelensky’s Oval Office Meeting Turned into a Showdown With Trump
description: The question hovering over Washington was whether the confrontation was a spontaneous outburst or a planned verbal smack down.
content: Just hours before President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine sat down with President Trump in the Oval Office on Friday, Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina dispensed some advice to the Ukrainian leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gavin Edwards
title: David Johansen, Who Fronted the New York Dolls and More, Dies at 75
description: In the 1970s, he and the transgressive Dolls were proto-punk pioneers. He later refashioned himself as the pompadoured lounge lizard Buster Poindexter.
content: David Johansen, the singer and songwriter who was at the vanguard of glam rock and punk as the frontman of the New York Dolls, died yesterday at his home on Staten Island. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Saint Laurent’s Big Bet on ‘Emilia Pérez’ Lost Its Luster
description: When a fashion brand becomes a movie studio, it risks being wrapped up in the fate of its stars.
content: Normally, the Sunday before Paris Fashion Week would be a day of frenetic activity for the Saint Laurent atelier and for its designer, Anthony Vaccarello. Normally, they would have only two more days to get ready for their fashion show, which has become one of the must-see opening events of the French collections. Normally, they would be rushing around, finalizing clothes, hair, makeup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: F.B.I. Returns Materials Taken From Mar-a-Lago to Trump
description: Among the items taken from the president’s Florida residence were files that investigators said contained classified material and formed the central evidence in one of the criminal cases against him.
content: The F.B.I. on Friday gave President Trump the boxes of materials the bureau had seized during a search of his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida in 2022, the White House announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Disney+, Amazon, Max, Apple TV+ and More in March
description: “Anora” and “Happy Face” arrive, and “‘Dark Winds,” “The Wheel of Time,” “The Righteous Gemstones” and more return.
content: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of March’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Connections Companion No. 630
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, March 2, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Julie Turkewitz
title: Lawsuit Against Panama Challenges Detention of Trump Deportees
description: A group of lawyers accused Panama of violating the rights of people deported from the United States under the Trump administration’s policy of sending migrants to cooperative Latin American nations.
content: A group of high-profile lawyers on Saturday filed a suit against Panama over its detention of migrants deported from the United States, threatening to disrupt President Trump’s new policy of exporting migrants from around the world to Central American countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: What Happens When a Broker Represents Both Sides of a Sale?
description: In New York, it is legal (though discouraged) for an agent to represent both the buyer and seller, or for members of the same team to represent both parties.
content: Q: My husband and I are buying a condo in Brooklyn. We found out that our real estate agent and the seller’s agent work in the same office and report to the same boss, and that the seller has done multiple deals with this team. During our negotiations, there have been a few issues, and the outcome is always that our agent bends to the will of the seller. What is the obligation of a real estate firm if it employs the agents on both sides of a deal? What rights do we have if we don’t feel a broker is objectively representing our interests?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Shocked by Trump, Zelensky and Ukraine Try to Forge a Path Forward
description: After President Trump’s rebukes, President Volodymyr Zelensky tried to repair the relationship with his counterpart while also reaching out to European allies.
content: For months leading into the American elections last fall, the prospect of a second Trump presidency deepened uncertainty among Ukrainians over how enduring American support would prove in a war threatening their national survival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘Yellowjackets’ Season 3, Episode 4 Recap: Judge, Jury and …
description: The girls (and Travis) put Coach Ben on trial. The stakes are very high, the legal qualifications very low.
content: What does justice look like to the Yellowjackets? It’s not pretty, it’s not logical, it’s often deeply unfair, and it’s all on display in this week’s episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Ulrich
title: Why Do S.U.V.s Look Like Trucks Again?
description: For decades, carlike curves were in. Now, buyers are interested in sport utility vehicles that feature right-angles and off-road cred.
content: Before the world heard of “sport utility vehicles,” they were called trucks: Jeeps, Land Rovers and Fords, many born as military vehicles, as square-jawed and capable as a drill sergeant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Joseph Gitnig, Central Park Minstrel Known as Pegasus, Dies at 95
description: For nearly two decades, he delighted children and adults in New York City with songs and silly antics. He also scored a victory for free speech.
content: Pegasus, the mythological winged stallion, symbolized divine inspiration and boundless freedom. So did Joseph Gitnig, the itinerant minstrel who called himself Pegasus and delighted children and adults who gathered spontaneously for nearly two decades to see him perform at the Central Park Zoo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Flow of U.S. Weapons to Ukraine Has Nearly Stopped and May End Completely
description: The Biden administration saw the $67 billion in military assistance it provided to Kyiv as essential. Trump sees any further aid as leverage.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine entered the White House for a meeting with President Donald Trump on Friday knowing that the flow of weapons and military hardware from the United States to his country had essentially stopped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: It’s Not Regular Pasta. It’s French Onion Pasta.
description: French onion orecchiette, to be exact, from the genius mind of Ham El-Waylly.
content: Onions, on their own, are pretty great. They’re inexpensive and they last a long time. Raw, they have an unmistakable sharp bite; sautéed, they become silky and sweet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Bell
title: An Island Family Faces Rising Waters and an Unexpected Guest
description: In Charlotte McConaghy’s novel “Wild Dark Shore,” the caretakers of a remote research base brave an escalating crisis.
content: Charlotte McConaghy’s third novel, “Wild Dark Shore,” opens vividly, with a shipwrecked woman named Rowan washing up on Shearwater, a remote island off the coast of Antarctica. She is nursed to health by the island’s caretakers — Dominic Salt and his children, Raff, Fen and Orly, the last inhabitants of an abandoned research base and seed bank — but her unexplained arrival soon upsets the Salt family’s delicate balance, which is already strained by grief amid a series of personal and professional disasters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Gynecologist Abused Patients While Defrauding Insurance, Officials Say
description: Dr. Sanjeev Kumar reused unsanitized medical equipment and subjected his patients to unnecessary tests and procedures for years, prosecutors said.
content: A gynecologist in Memphis who reused unsanitary equipment on his patients was arrested on Friday and charged with sexually abusing patients over five years and profiting from insurance fraud, according to federal prosecutors and court records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Democrats See Political Opening in G.O.P. Budget as Republicans Eye Medicaid Cuts
description: Democrats are rerunning the playbook that won them control of Congress in 2018, focusing on the cost of the G.O.P.’s tax cut plan for ordinary Americans, particularly when it comes to health care.
content: In 2018, Democrats won back the House, flipping 41 seats including in conservative-leaning places like the suburbs of Utah and Oklahoma by focusing narrowly on a single issue: Republican efforts to overturn a popular health care program, the Affordable Care Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Cuomo’s Foes Look to Renew Focus on Sexual Harassment Scandal
description: As Andrew M. Cuomo runs for mayor, political opponents are previewing attack lines regarding the harassment accusations that led to his resignation as governor.
content: In the months before he joined New York City’s mayoral race, Andrew M. Cuomo sought to create as much distance as possible from the sexual harassment scandal that forced him to resign as governor more than three years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: In Pittsburgh, Many Sentiments About Pope’s Health Reflect Concern, Not Closeness
description: On a recent weekend in this once deeply Catholic city, many expressed worry about Pope Francis, but there was also an air of ambivalence.
content: Congregants escaping the winter morning’s chill trickled into Immaculate Heart of Mary Church for Sunday Mass last weekend. There was a time when the massive brick church, which stands like a beacon atop Pittsburgh’s Polish Hill neighborhood, would have been packed with parishioners who lived in the surrounding blocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: ‘Why Don’t You Wear a Suit?’: A Right-Wing News Outlet With Coveted Access Questions Zelensky
description: After the White House began to handpick pool reporters, Brian Glenn of the conservative Real America’s Voice network got to be front and center for the Ukrainian president’s visit.
content: A voice from the press section joined the chorus of people demanding answers from President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Friday, during a meeting with President Trump and his associates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: As Trump Overhauls the Military, Fort Bragg and Its Neighbors Brace for Change
description: The fortunes of Fayetteville, N.C., are tied to the nearby Army base. What should the city expect with the Trump administration firing top leaders and planning budget cuts?
content: When Marvin Samuels, a veteran who served more than 20 years in the Army, recently opened a restaurant in Fayetteville, N.C., he chose a special name: Liberty Island Foods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Go Behind the Scenes of All 10 Best Picture Oscar Nominees
description: In these videos, directors walked us through pivotal scenes from their 2025 Academy Award-nominated films.
content: Oscars 2025: Follow live updates on the 97th Academy Awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Geoffrey Rush Lives for the Roar of the Crowd
description: “If you sit at home, you are not sharing your own private experience of what the general pulse of the world is,” said the actor, who stars in the horror film “The Rule of Jenny Pen.”
content: Geoffrey Rush has rarely met a physical task he didn’t want to attempt, be it sword fighting for “Pirates of the Caribbean” or playing the piano for his Oscar-winning role in “Shine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Qasim Nauman and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Trump Says He Will Posthumously Pardon the Baseball Star Pete Rose
description: President Trump also repeated his call for Rose, who was banned from the sport for gambling, to be inducted into the Hall of Fame.
content: President Trump said late Friday that he would grant a full pardon to Pete Rose, who was one of baseball’s greatest players before he spectacularly fell from grace for gambling on games while he was a player and manager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Lukk Litwak
title: The Next Big Architecture Movie? A Few Predictions.
description: As “The Brutalist” heads into Oscar night with 10 nominations, Hollywood is clamoring for its next big architecture hit. Our illustrator has some ideas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Goldstone
title: America Is Pushing Its Workers Into Homelessness
description: The working homeless are casualties of our prosperity.
content: At 10 p.m., a hospital technician pulls into a Walmart parking lot. Her four kids — one still nursing — are packed into the back of her Toyota. She tells them it’s an adventure, but she’s terrified someone will call the police: “Inadequate housing” is enough to lose your children. She stays awake for hours, lavender scrubs folded in the trunk, listening for footsteps, any sign of trouble. Her shift starts soon. She’ll walk into the hospital exhausted, pretending everything is fine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: What Republican Men Think About Trump and Masculinity
description: The election seemed to mark a backlash to changing gender roles. But Trump-voting men say that’s not necessarily what they want, a survey and interviews suggest.
content: President Trump’s re-election seemed to mark a cultural turning point on gender — a backlash to #MeToo and other progress for women’s rights, and a return to a time when men could be men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: How to Watch the Oscars: Date, Time and Streaming
description: Conan O’Brien will host the annual awards, which will be available to watch live on a streaming service for the first time.
content: Oscars 2025: Follow live updates on the 97th Academy Awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison and Christine Zhang
title: The Stock Market Was One of Trump’s Favorite Talking Points. Not Lately.
description: Since his inauguration last month, President Trump has been relatively muted about the stock market. Investors are getting worried about an impending sell-off.
content: Since his inauguration last month, President Trump has been relatively muted about the stock market. Investors are getting worried about an impending sell-off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: 10 Columnists and Writers Rate What Mattered in Trump’s First Full Month
description: From DOGE to Ukraine to the Eric Adams case, these are the most consequential actions by the new administration so far.
content: From DOGE to Ukraine to the Eric Adams case, these are the most consequential actions by the new administration so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Fitzsimmons, Melanie Bencosme and Karen Hanley
title: Andrew Cuomo Enters N.Y.C. Mayoral Race
description: Andrew Cuomo is running for mayor of New York City, four years after he resigned in disgrace as governor of New York State. Emma G. Fitzsimmons, the City Hall bureau chief for The New York Times, looks at his comeback attempt.
content: Andrew Cuomo is running for mayor of New York City, four years after he resigned in disgrace as governor of New York State. Emma G. Fitzsimmons, the City Hall bureau chief for The New York Times, looks at his comeback attempt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green, Gabriel Blanco, Rebecca Suner, Nikolay Nikolov and Laura Salaberry
title: Trump Berates Zelensky and Putin Benefits
description: The United States’ relationship with Ukraine erupted in a storm of acrimony on Friday as President Trump and Vice President JD Vance berated President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in an explosive televised Oval Office showdown and abruptly cut short a visit meant to coordinate a plan for peace. Erica Green, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, breaks it down.
content: The United States’ relationship with Ukraine erupted in a storm of acrimony on Friday as President Trump and Vice President JD Vance berated President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in an explosive televised Oval Office showdown and abruptly cut short a visit meant to coordinate a plan for peace. Erica Green, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, breaks it down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson, Gabriel Blanco, Karen Hanley and Laura Salaberry
title: What’s Wrong With the International Oscar Category
description: At the Oscars, the rules set around the best international film category mean that some of the best movies are not even being nominated. Our movie critic explains why, and what could be done to fix the problem. She uses examples from “The Zone of Interest” set in German-occupied Poland, “All We Imagine as Light” in India, “the Room Next Door” set in Spain and “the Seed of the Sacred Fig,” filmed and based in Iran.
content: At the Oscars, the rules set around the best international film category mean that some of the best movies are not even being nominated. Our movie critic explains why, and what could be done to fix the problem. She uses examples from “The Zone of Interest” set in German-occupied Poland, “All We Imagine as Light” in India, “the Room Next Door” set in Spain and “the Seed of the Sacred Fig,” filmed and based in Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A FedEx Cargo Plane’s Engine Caught on Fire While Leaving Newark Airport
description: There were no reported injuries after a FedEx cargo plane’s engine caught on fire, forcing it to make an emergency landing at Newark Liberty International Airport, officials said.
content: There were no reported injuries after a FedEx cargo plane’s engine caught on fire, forcing it to make an emergency landing at Newark Liberty International Airport, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Christina Thornell, Amber Bracken and David Jouppi
title: Why Canada Is Trying to Secure the Border
description: Since President Trump’s election, Canada has intensified its efforts to curb illegal immigration into the U.S. However, with mass deportations underway in the U.S., a new dynamic is emerging at the border. Matina Stevis-Gridneff, The New York Times’s Canada bureau chief, reports from the border.
content: Since President Trump’s election, Canada has intensified its efforts to curb illegal immigration into the U.S. However, with mass deportations underway in the U.S., a new dynamic is emerging at the border. Matina Stevis-Gridneff, The New York Times’s Canada bureau chief, reports from the border.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Gov. Maura Healey Wants Democrats to Put Up a Fight
description: The Massachusetts leader, whose influence goes well beyond her state, discusses how the Democratic Party can pick its battles and rebuild its brand.
content: The Massachusetts leader, whose influence goes well beyond her state, discusses how the Democratic Party can pick its battles and rebuild its brand.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Dark Heart of Trump’s Foreign Policy
description: The journalist Fareed Zakaria discusses the worldview emerging from Trump’s foreign policy decisions regarding Ukraine, Gaza, China and beyond.
content: The journalist Fareed Zakaria discusses the worldview emerging from Trump’s foreign policy decisions regarding Ukraine, Gaza, China and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times
